sections.title: A Part-\b\t-sp\f\fch tagg\fr \t\br Irish using Finit\f-Stat\f M\brph\bl\bgy and C\bnstraint Grammar Disambiguati\bn E. Uí Dh\bnnchadha
, J. Van G\fnabith
paragraphs: Centre \b\tr Lan\fua\fe and C\tmmunicati\tn Studies
Trinity C\tlle\fe, Dublin 2, Ireland 2 Nati\tnal Centre \b\tr Lan\fua\fe Techn\tl\t\fy
Dublin City University, Glasnevin, Dublin 9, Ireland
uidh\tnne@tcd.ie j\tse\b@c\tmputin\f.dcu.ie

Abstract This paper describes the meth\td\tl\t\fy used t\t devel\tp a part-\t\b-speech ta\f\fer \b\tr Irish, which is used t\t ann\ttate a c\trpus \t\b 30 milli\tn w\trds \t\b text with part-\t\b-speech ta\fs and lemmas. The ta\f\fer is evaluated usin\f a manually disambi\fuated test c\trpus and it currently achieves 95% accuracy \tn unrestricted text. T\t \tur kn\twled\fe, this is the \birst part-\t\b-speech ta\f\fer \b\tr Irish.

sections.title: 1. Intr\bducti\bn
paragraphs: This paper describes the meth\td\tl\t\fy used t\t devel\tp a part-\t\b-speech ta\f\fer \b\tr Irish. The ta\f\fer is used t\t ann\ttate a c\trpus \t\b 30 milli\tn w\trds \t\b text (Kil\farri\b\b et al, \b\trthc\tmin\f) with part-\t\b-speech ta\fs and lemmas. The text is ann\ttated usin\f Par\tle m\trph\t-syntactic ta\fs (ITÉ, 2002; Calz\tlari et al, 1996) and XML C\trpus Enc\tdin\f Standard (XCES, 2002).

The ta\f\fer is evaluated usin\f a manually disambi\fuated test c\trpus and it currently achieves 95% accuracy \tn unrestricted text. T\t \tur kn\twled\fe, this is the \birst part-\t\b-speech ta\f\fer devel\tped \b\tr Irish.

Secti\tn 2 presents the meth\td\tl\t\fy used in \tur appr\tach. Secti\tn 3 describes \tur test c\trpus and presents \tverall results. Secti\tn 4 pr\tvides a detailed err\tr analysis and secti\tn 5 c\tncludes with an \tutline \t\b \burther w\trk.

sections.title: 2. M\fth\bd\bl\bgy
paragraphs: We implement the part-\t\b-speech ta\f\fer in three sta\fes: t\tkenizati\tn, m\trph\tl\t\fical analysis \t\b t\tkens and part-\t\b-speech disambi\fuati\tn \t\b the m\trph\tl\t\fical analyses. T\tkenizati\tn and m\trph\tl\t\fical analysis are carried \tut usin\f \binite-state transducers \b\tll\twin\f Beesley and Karttunen (2003). The m\trph\tl\t\fical analysis \b\tr each t\tken results, in m\tst cases, in a number \t\b p\tssible analyses. C\tnstraint Grammar (Tapanainen, 1996) rules are then used t\t ch\t\tse the c\trrect analysis \fiven the c\tntext in which the t\tken is \b\tund.

A rule-based appr\tach is used thr\tu\fh\tut in \trder t\t expl\tit the rich in\blecti\tnal m\trph\tl\t\fy \t\b Irish. This will als\t \b\trm the basis \b\tr \buture w\trk such as chunkin\f and parsin\f.

sections.title: 2.1. T\bk\fnizati\bn
paragraphs: Irish text can be se\fmented, t\t a lar\fe extent, acc\trdin\f t\t the white space between w\trds. In m\tst cases a t\tken c\tnsists \t\b a w\trd \tr punctuati\tn symb\tl as in (1). H\twever, a w\trd may c\tnsist \t\b m\tre than \tne t\tken (2) and a t\tken can c\tnsist \t\b m\tre than \tne w\trd (3). Numbers, dates and abbreviati\tns als\t require special c\tnsiderati\tn.

sections.title: = Tar éis Cé is moite "except" : t
= Cé is m\tite  2.2. M\brph\bl\bgical Analysis
paragraphs: The stream \t\b t\tkens (4) is pr\tcessed by a sequence \t\b m\trph\tl\t\fical analysers and \fuessers (Uí Dh\tnnchadha and Van Genabith, 2005) as implemented in (Beesley and Karttunen, 2003).

sections.title: 4) a\b maith leis úlla? "d\tes he like apples?"
paragraphs: Each t\tken is analysed, with\tut re\berence t\t c\tntext, and receives a number \t\b p\tssible analyses.

sections.title: 5) \f<a\b>\f "an" Art S\f De\b "an" Part Vb Q "is" C\tp Pres Q "is" C\tp Pres Dep Q 6) "<maith>" "maith" Adj Base "maith" Adj Masc C\tm S\f "maith" Adj Gen Weak Pl "maith" N\tun Fem C\tm S\f "maith" Verb VTI Imper 2P S\f 7) "<leis"> "leis" N\tun Fem C\tm S\f "le" Pr\tn Prep 3P S\f Masc "le" Pr\tn Simp 2241 8) "<úlla>" "úll" N\tun Masc C\tm Pl "úll" N\tun Masc V\tc Pl 9) "<?>" "?" Punct Fin Q 2.3. C\bnstraint Grammar Disambiguati\bn
paragraphs: C\tnstraint Grammar (CG) (Tapanainen, 1996) rules are used t\t pr\tcess the \tutput \t\b the m\trph\tl\t\fical analyzer. In the examples bel\tw we re\ber t\t example sentence (4). CG rules \tperate \tver all the t\tkens in a sentence, where each sentence is delimited by a punctuati\tn mark (e.\f. .!? etc.) \tr an XML ta\f (e.\f. </s>). In CG, each sentence is described in terms \t\b c\th\trts (5,6,7,8,9), readin\fs ("a\b" has \b\tur readin\fs, "maith" has \bive, etc.) and ta\fs (e.\f. Art S\f De\b). A c\th\trt c\tnsists \t\b a t\tken and all the p\tssible readin\fs \b\tr that t\tken. Each readin\f includes a lemma, m\trph\tl\t\fical ta\fs and p\tssibly \frammatical \buncti\tn ta\fs.

T\t select the m\tst likely m\trph\tl\t\fical analysis \b\tr an ambi\fu\tus t\tken, CG uses \tther c\th\trts within the sentence. A p\tsiti\tnal re\berence system is used whereby the c\th\trt under c\tnsiderati\tn is at p\tsiti\tn 0, the \b\tll\twin\f c\th\trt is at p\tsiti\tn 1 and the previ\tus c\th\trt is at p\tsiti\tn –1, and s\t \tn.

There are tw\t basic types \t\b rule: ‘select’ and ‘rem\tve’. Select rules are used t\t ch\t\tse the appr\tpriate readin\f \br\tm a c\th\trt based \tn the c\tntext t\t the le\bt and/\tr ri\fht. I\b this is n\tt p\tssible, rem\tve rules may delete imp\tssible/unlikely readin\fs \br\tm a c\th\trt based \tn the c\tntext, and h\tpe\bully \tnly the c\trrect readin\f will remain.

(10) \fives an example \t\b a rule which selects n\tun readin\f(s) i\b the previ\tus t\tken is unambi\fu\tusly (C=care\bul) an article. Example (11) sh\tws a rule which rem\tves the v\tcative case readin\f \br\tm "úlla" in (8), as it is n\tt preceded by a v\tcative particle.
10) SELECT (N\tun) IF (-1C (Art)); 11) REMOVE (N\tun V\tc) IF (NOT -1 (Part V\tc));

In c\th\trts (5) t\t (9) we cann\tt select readin\fs strai\fht away but we can rem\tve readin\fs. F\tr instance, an interr\t\fative verbal particle "a\b" cann\tt precede an imperative verbal \b\trm, there\b\tre we can rem\tve this readin\f, leavin\f just the p\tssibility \t\b article \tr c\tpula. In the case \t\b "maith", since a verb cann\tt directly \b\tll\tw an article \tr a c\tpula this readin\f is rem\tved, leavin\f n\tun and adjective readin\fs. Further CG rules are applied until the analysis (12) is achieved.

sections.title: 12) \f<a\b>\f "is" C\tp Pres Q "<maith>" "maith" Adj Base "<leis"> "le" Pr\tn Prep 3P S\f Masc "<úlla>" "úll" N\tun Masc C\tm Pl "<?>" "?" Punct Fin Q
paragraphs: In \trder t\t implement the ta\f\fer we c\tded \tver three hundred CG disambi\fuati\tn rules based \tn the main syntactic patterns in Irish. S\tme t\tkens remain ambi\fu\tus as we c\tnservatively leave a ch\tice \t\b readin\fs rather than risk an inc\trrect selecti\tn.

sections.title: 3. Evaluati\bn
paragraphs: Our evaluati\tn \b\tcused \tn tw\t aspects \t\b the disambi\fuati\tn pr\tcess a) the percenta\fe \t\b ambi\fu\tus t\tkens remainin\f a\bter pr\tcessin\f and b) the accuracy \t\b the disambi\fuati\tn. In l\t\tkin\f at ambi\fu\tus t\tkens \tur aim is t\t ascertain the cause \t\b the ambi\fuity and t\t devise new rules, where p\tssible, t\t eliminate the ambi\fuity. Currently 97% \t\b t\tkens in \tur test c\trpus (see bel\tw) are disambi\fuated with re\fard t\t POS cate\f\try. H\twever, 7% \t\b these t\tkens still c\tntain s\tme in\blecti\tnal \tr lemma ambi\fuity.

sections.title: 3.1. T\fst C\brpus
paragraphs: In \trder t\t assess the accuracy \t\b the disambi\fuati\tn pr\tcess, we created a sub-c\trpus \t\b 3,000 rand\tmly selected sentences (70,000 t\tkens appr\tx.) \br\tm the 30 milli\tn w\trd c\trpus. This sub-c\trpus was then rand\tmly distributed int\t tw\t parts, with appr\tximately tw\t thirds \b\tr devel\tpment and \tne third held-\tut \b\tr testin\f \t\b CG based disambi\fuati\tn rules. Each t\tken in the devel\tpment and test c\trpus was manually disambi\fuated.

sections.title: 3.2. Ov\frall Analysis
paragraphs: The test c\trpus was aut\tmatically disambi\fuated by \tur CG ta\f\fer. The \tutc\tme was a 95% accuracy \b\tr part- \t\b-speech cate\f\try (increasin\f t\t 96% when ambi\fu\tus t\tkens are included). H\twever i\b additi\tnal \beatures are taken int\t c\tnsiderati\tn (e.\f. case, number etc.) accuracy dr\tps t\t 93%.

We evaluate each sta\fe \t\b the ta\f\fin\f pr\tcess by examinin\f the di\b\berences between the manually ta\f\fed text and the aut\tmatically ta\f\fed text. In this manner, we are able t\t determine whether the discrepancies arise at the t\tkenizati\tn, m\trph\tl\t\fical analysis \tr POS disambi\fuati\tn sta\fes.

sections.title: 4. Err\br Analysis 4.1. T\bk\fnizati\bn
paragraphs: T\tkenizati\tn is assessed by c\tmparin\f the ali\fnment between the aut\tmatically t\tkenized \tutput and the test c\trpus. Misali\fnments are due either t\t sh\trtc\tmin\fs in the t\tkenizer \tr mal\b\trmed input. All \t\b the t\tkenizer pr\tblems enc\tuntered related t\t instances where punctuati\tn sh\tuld n\tt have been separated \br\tm the t\tken, as in the case \t\b c\tntracti\tns like im' meanin\f "i mo" (in my) etc. This was addressed by addin\f speci\bic re\fular expressi\tns t\t the t\tkenizer t\t deal with these cases.
Toke\bizer problems:
• c\tntracti\tns, e.\f. im' (i mo - in my) a's (agus -
and), 'u\b (\thu\b - t\twards), a' (a\b/ag - the/at)
• numbers with trailin\f punctuati\tn, e.\f. 1995.
• items which sh\tuld stay t\t\fether, e.\f. (iii), (B)
• email & urls, e.\f. pa\b\telti\t@eir\tom.\bet,
www.o\beworld.\tom
• abbreviati\tns gCo., Uimh., CD-ROM • pr\tper names with En\flish \fenitive, e.\f.
Madiga\b's, Pete's Pizzas

A certain am\tunt \t\b mal\b\trmed input will always be enc\tuntered when pr\tcessin\f lar\fe am\tunts \t\b unrestricted text. H\twever, mal\b\trmed strin\fs in the devel\tpment sub-c\trpus, were c\trrected in \trder t\t pr\tvide a \f\t\td basis \b\tr rule inducti\tn at a later sta\fe.  Malformed i\bput:
• w\trd split int\t tw\t, e.\f. fa\b- faidh, ra\th aidh,
• tw\t w\trds j\tined, e.\f. séama\th, (sé ama\th),
\téa\tu (\té a\tu)

sections.title: 4.2. M\brph\bl\bgical Analysis
paragraphs: Each t\tken is analysed \b\tr lemma, part-\t\b-speech
cate\f\try, and \tther m\trph\t-syntactic \beatures (tense,
m\t\td, \fender, number etc.). Each t\tken is assi\fned \tne \tr
m\tre analysis by \tne \t\b the \b\tll\twin\f meth\tds: • \bindin\f the t\tken in the \binite-state lexic\tn • \bindin\f the r\t\tt \t\b the t\tken in the lexic\tn plus
standard pre\bixes \tr su\b\bixes • \bindin\f a c\tmp\tund made up \t\b items \b\tund in
the lexic\tn, • predictin\f the t\tken's characteristics based \tn
in\blecti\tnal \tr derivati\tnal a\b\bixes, capitalisati\tn,
v\twel structure \t\b the \binal syllable, \tr \tther
distinctive characteristics.

On avera\fe 95% \t\b t\tkens are \b\tund in the lexic\tn usin\f \tne \t\b the \birst three meth\tds, and are ass\tciated with an appr\tpriate lemma, part-\t\b-speech cate\f\try and m\trph\t-syntactic \beatures. The remainder are assi\fned a \fuessed analysis usin\f predictive strate\fies (\fuessers). They tend t\t pr\tduce the c\trrect POS and \beatures, alth\tu\fh the lemmas pr\tduced tend t\t be m\tre pr\tblematic due t\t internal chan\fes t\t m\trphemes. In a \bew cases m\tre than \tne p\tssible head is identi\bied in a c\tmp\tund, and the c\trrect \tne may n\tt always be ch\tsen (see Uí Dh\tnnchadha and Van Genabith, 2005).

Discrepancies between the manually ta\f\fed and aut\tmatically ta\f\fed text can arise at the m\trph\tl\t\fical analysis sta\fe when the analysis assi\fned manually is n\tt pr\tvided by the m\trph\tl\t\fical analyzer. Either the lexeme is in the lexic\tn but is missin\f the required analysis, \tr it is n\tt in the lexic\tn and the \fuessed analysis is n\tt the appr\tpriate \tne \b\tr the c\tntext.  Examples \t\b missin\f lexemes
• n\tn-standard spellin\f \t\b \buncti\tn w\trds e.\f.
fúithe (fúithi - under her), léithe (léi - with her),
daofa (dóibh/díobh - t\t them/\br\tm them)
• n\tn-standard verb \b\trms, e.\f. atáid, bhfuilimíd,
bhfea\taíos Examples \t\b missin\f analyses
• adj. as well as n\tun analysis required, e.\f.
\toitea\b\b (c\tmm\tn)
• verbal n\tun as well as c\tmm\tn n\tun required

e.\f. ias\tairea\tht (\bishin\f)  There are tw\t ways \t\b dealin\f with missin\f lexemes, a) by addin\f m\tre items t\t the lexic\tn and b) by impr\tvin\f the \fuessers' strate\fy. The l\tn\fer term \tbjective is t\t increase the lexic\tns (which currently c\tntain appr\tx. 30K stems), but an examinati\tn \t\b the types \t\b items which are missin\f reveals that we can deal with s\tme speci\bic areas immediately. Apart \br\tm missin\f \tpen class w\trds (n\tuns, verbs and adjectives), and th\tse caused by typ\t\fraphical err\trs, we \bind that many \t\b the members \t\b the \buncti\tnal class \t\b c\tnju\fated prep\tsiti\tns (prep\tsiti\tnal pr\tn\tuns) have dialectal variants which can be added t\t the lexic\tn. In additi\tn, a number \t\b n\tn-standard in\blected verb \b\trms n\tt included in current re\berence \frammars (Bráithre Crí\tstaí, 1999), are n\tw bein\f \fenerated by the m\trph\tl\t\fical transducers.

Additi\tnal analyses are added \b\tr speci\bic lexemes where necessary, but we d\t n\tt say that all n\tuns can be adjectives \tr vice versa, as this w\tuld intr\tduce a detrimental level \t\b ambi\fuity.

Particular attenti\tn was paid t\t the e\b\bectiveness \t\b the \fuessers as we can never expect t\t achieve 100% c\tvera\fe with the m\trph\tl\t\fical analysers al\tne. The \trder in which \fuessers are tried is imp\trtant. In \tur implementati\tn a sequence \t\b \fuessers are tried until \tne succeeds, e.\f. \birst we check i\b the unrec\t\fnised t\tken c\tuld be a pre\bixed \tr su\b\bixed lexeme, \tr i\b it has a verb in\blecti\tnal su\b\bix, \tr i\b it is a c\tmp\tund \t\b tw\t lexemes. I\b these \bail we l\t\tk at the last syllable \t\b the t\tken \b\tr clues as t\t its POS and m\trph\tl\t\fical \beatures.

A pr\tblem was n\tted where s\tme c\tmm\tn w\trd-\binal m\trphemes e.\f. -ea\th(a), -a\tht as in (13) and (14) ,which are h\tm\tnyms \t\b lexemes ea\th and a\tht, were bein\f analysed as c\tmp\tund heads. A new \fuesser was intr\tduced t\t test \b\tr such w\trd-\binal m\trphemes be\b\tre testin\f \b\tr c\tmp\tunds.
13) truslóga\tht (jumpin\f) n\tt truslóg (jump) + a\tht
(act - \t\b parliament)
14) shea\bmháthairea\tha (\frandm\tthers) n\tt
shea\bmháthair (\frandm\tther) + ea\tha (h\trses)

An\tther issue which came t\t li\fht is the \bact that in s\tme cases it is necessary t\t supply multiple \fuessed analyses. Previ\tusly \tnly the m\tst likely analysis was \fenerated but there are a \bew su\b\bixes where several analyses are equally likely, e.\f. -adh c\tuld indicate either a verb \b\trm, a c\tmm\tn n\tun \tr a verbal n\tun, als\t -tí c\tuld be a verbal \tr n\tminal su\b\bix.

sections.title: 4.3. CG Disambiguati\bn
paragraphs: CG disambi\fuati\tn achieves \tverall 95% accuracy \b\tr part-\t\b-speech cate\f\try. In \trder t\t \b\tcus \tur e\b\b\trts in impr\tvin\f per\b\trmance, individual accuracy statistics were c\tmputed \b\tr each \t\b twenty part-\t\b-speech cate\f\tries. Table 1 sh\tws individual results (\br\tm the devel\tpment sub-c\trpus) ran\fin\f \br\tm 99% t\t 61%. In \trder t\t impr\tve results we \b\tcus \tur attenti\tn \tn the distincti\tn between n\tun classes as they acc\tunt \b\tr the \freatest number \t\b t\tkens pr\tp\trti\tnally, and als\t the c\tpula and numerals.
Table 1 Ta\f\fin\f accuracy per POS cate\f\try

sections.title: POS D\fscripti\bn POS  N\b. \b\t t\bk\fns % C\brr\fct Article Td 2913 99 Adverb R 833 98 Pr\tn\tun P 3082 96 Prep\tsiti\tn Sp 7119 95 C\tnjuncti\tn C 2706 94 Particle: verb. Q 1600 94 N\tun: c\tmm. Nc 11429 93 Verb Vm 3762 92 Abbreviati\tn Y 142 89 Determiner D 1365 88 Adjective Aq 2110 87 N\tun: subst. Ns 303 87 N\tun: pr\tper Np 1715 86 N\tun: verbal Nv 1718 80 Particle: \tth. U 497 80 F\trei\fn X 510 78 C\tpula W 770 77 Interjecti\tn I 15 73 Adj.: verbal Av 331 68 Numeral M 754 61
paragraphs: We als\t examined the m\tst c\tmm\tn types \t\b POS ambi\fuity, presented in Table 2. The m\tst c\tmm\tn type \t\b ambi\fuity is between tw\t classes \t\b n\tun. In ta\f\fin\f, we distin\fuish between c\tmm\tn n\tuns (15) and verbal n\tuns (15) (m\tst \t\b which are de-verbal \tr de-a\fentive). Verbal n\tuns can \tccur in syntactic c\tnstructi\tns where c\tmm\tn n\tuns cann\tt (16). H\twever, ambi\fuity arises \br\tm the \bact that all verbal n\tuns can \buncti\tn as c\tmm\tn n\tuns (18).
a\b doras (the d\t\tr) - art + n\tun
ag freastal (servin\f) - prep (asp.) + verbal n\tun
*ag doras (d\t\trin\f) - prep (asp.) + n\tun ag doras (at d\t\tr) - prep (l\tc.) + n\tun

sections.title: Ambigu\bus Class\fs t\bk\fns % N c\tmm. vs. N verbal 283 11.5 N c\tmm. vs. Adj 240 9.7 N c\tmm. vs. Verb 179 7.2 N c\tmm. vs. N pr\tper 153 6.2 N pr\tp vs. F\trei\fn 122 4.9 N verbal vs. Verb 113 4.6 Prep. vs. Det. p\tss. 82 3.3 Prep. vs. V particle 76 3.0 Number vs. Prep 75 3.0 N c\tmm. vs. F\trei\fn 66 2.6  180 \tther types \t\b ambi\fuity 1080 43.7 T\ttal 2469 100.0
paragraphs: N\tun-adjective ambi\fuity is the next m\tst c\tmm\tn type \t\b discrepancy between the manually and aut\tmatically ta\f\fed texts. Analysis \t\b the results in Table 2 is \tn\f\tin\f and will lead t\t re\binement \t\b the existin\f rules and the creati\tn \t\b new rules. Table 2 sh\tws that the ten m\tst c\tmm\tn ambi\fuities acc\tunt \b\tr \tver hal\b \t\b the di\b\berences enc\tuntered between the tw\t c\trp\tra.

sections.title: 5. Furth\fr W\brk
paragraphs: W\trk has be\fun \tn aut\tmatically inducin\f new CG rules by pr\tcessin\f the manually ta\f\fed c\trpus, \b\tll\twin\f Samuelss\tn et al. (1996). Bi\fram and uni\fram \brequency statistics are used t\t identi\by likely and unlikely ta\f c\tmbinati\tns. Data \tn phrase patterns are als\t c\tllected. This in\b\trmati\tn is used t\t aut\tmatically create CG rules. These rules it is h\tped will c\tmplement the hand-written CG rules and aid us in reachin\f \tur tar\fet \t\b 97%-99% accuracy, c\tmparable t\t state-\t\b-the-art ta\f\fers \b\tr En\flish and \tther techn\tl\t\fically advanced lan\fua\fes.

sections.title: 6. R\f\t\fr\fnc\fs
paragraphs: Beesley K. & Karttunen L., 2003. Fi\bite State Morphology. CSLI Publicati\tns: Cali\b\trnia.
Bráithre Crí\tstaí, 1999. Graiméar Gaeilge \ba mBráithre Críostaí. 2nd. ed. Baile Átha Cliath: An Gúm
Calz\tlari, N., M\tnachini, M., (1996). Multext. http://www.lpl.univ-aix.\br/pr\tjects/multext/LEX/LEX1. html (accessed March 2006).
